comment.author: 64403351@N08
comment._content: I think the date is wrong. I was looking through the shipping news to identify the two large ships adjacent to Bennelong Point and the Sydney Morning Herald reported severe storms, gales and flooding in the first few days of June 1930. The lack of shadows would suggest this is in summer, not winter.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/davidbromage] Oh goody a bit of controversy... ! Watching with interest. Btw how do you tell HMAS 'Australia' and 'Canberra' apart? They are the subject of ongoing confusion over on the ANMM stream. eg www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/7332270140/ www.flickr.com/photos/33147718@N05/8293272990

comment.author: 97539983@N07
comment._content: This photo id dated 17 days later, yet the same ships are still moored at Garden Island and Bennelong Point. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/10733438483/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I'd say the pic was taken in mid year...the construction of the arch looks too advanced for the date to have been earlier in the year...keeping in mind the lower chord was joined on 19/8/1930; the upper chord on 10/9/1930. The lack of movement in the shipping in the two pics is interesting though...I gather the date accompanying the NSW Public Works Dept pics refers to the date taken...rather than say the date developed...I dare say it's possible that from time to time  occasional errors were made in recording dates...though you'd think the engineers would have taken a good deal of care to ensure the chronology of the pictorial record was spot on...establishing the identities and movements of the two ships at Bennelong Point might shed some light...

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: It looks kind of wintry to me.
